questions.question: Question 1: Which of these is not a form of sphingolipidoses?
questions.explanation:
Hurler disease is a mucopolysaccharidosis. Sphingolipidoses are a group of lysosomal storage disorders characterized by the accumulation of 
sphingolipids. It includes: • Niemann–Pick disease • Fabry disease • Krabbe disease • Gaucher disease • Tay–Sachs disease • Metachromatic leukodystrophy

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common lysosomal storage disorder?
questions.explanation:
Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder. 170 
Sold by @itachibot It is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting from mutations in the gene encoding 
glucocerebrosidase.

questions.question:
Question 3: An 8-month-old child presents with mental retardation, blindness, and muscle weakness. On 
evaluation, deficiency of hexosaminidase -subunit is found. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given scenario and hexosaminidase -subunit deficiency are seen in Tay–Sachs disease. Sphingolipidoses with their deficient enzyme: • GM1 Gangliosidoses - GM1 Ganglioside  - galactosidase deficiency • Type 1- infantile, generalizsed • Type 2- juvenile • GM2 Gangliosidosis: • Tay–Sachs disease - Hexosaminidase -subunit • Sandhoff disease - Hexosaminidase  -subunit • GM2 Gangliosidosis variant AB - Ganglioside activator protein Note: Tay–Sachs disease is the most common form of GM2 gangliosidosis.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements is false about Tay–Sachs Disease?

options.a: Affected infants are normal at birth
options.b: Neurons in the CNS, ANS, and retina are affected
options.c: Accumulations stain positive for oil red O and Sudan black B
options.d: Whorled configurations within mitochondria are seen

questions.explanation:
In Tay–Sachs disease, an electron microscope shows whorled configurations within lysosomes 
composed of onion-skin layers of membranes. Affected infants appear normal at birth but begin to manifest signs and symptoms at about 6 
months of age. The involvement of neurons in the central and autonomic nervous systems and 
retina dominates the clinical picture. There is a severe motor and mental deterioration, beginning with motor incoordination and 
mental obtundation. This leads to muscular flaccidity, blindness, and increasing dementia. Over 
the span of 1 or 2 years, a completely vegetative state is reached, followed by death at age 2 to 3 
years On histologic examination, the neurons are ballooned with cytoplasmic vacuoles, each 
representing a markedly distended lysosome filled with gangliosides. A cherry-red spot appears in the macula, representing the accentuation of the normal color of the 
macular choroid. This is in contrast with the pallor produced by the swollen ganglion cells in the 
remainder of the retina. This finding is characteristic of Tay-Sachs disease and other storage 
disorders affecting the neurons. The image given below shows a cherry-red spot on retina. 171 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: Patients with metachromatic leukodystrophy will have which of the following enzyme 
deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive condition caused by the deficiency of 
arylsulfatase A. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of cerebroside sulfate. These sulfatides 
can contribute to white matter injury, demyelination, and gliosis. Macrophages with vacuolated cytoplasm are scattered throughout the white matter. They contain 
metachromatic material, which can be detected in the urine and peripheral nerves when stained 
with toluidine blue.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following enzyme is deficient in patients with Krabbe disease?
questions.explanation:
Krabbe disease is due to the deficiency of galactosylceramidase. The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as 
stiffness and weakness. They often don't survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows loss 
of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves. The aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma and 
around blood vessels is the characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease.

questions.question: Question 7: Patients with which of the following diseases will have ceramide trihexoside accumulation?
questions.explanation:
Ceramide trihexoside (also known as globotriaosylceramide) is accumulated in Fabry disease. The enzyme defect seen in this disease is -galactosidase A. 172 
Sold by @itachibot Clinical features: • Painful acroparaesthesia • Hypohidrosis • Abdominal cramping • Diarrhea • Small petechiae around the umbilicus • Lenticular opacities • Corneal dystrophy

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following statements is false about Niemann–Pick disease?

options.a: Inherited deficiency of aryl sulfatase is present

questions.explanation:
Niemann–Pick disease types A and B are two related disorders that are characterized by lysosomal 
accumulation of sphingomyelin due to an inherited deficiency of sphingomyelinase. The disease is typically inherited as an autosomal recessive condition on chromosome 11. Type A is a severe infantile form with extensive neurologic involvement, marked visceral 
accumulations of sphingomyelin, progressive wasting, and early death within the first 3 years of 
life. Type B disease patients have organomegaly, but generally no central nervous system involvement. 
They usually survive into adulthood.

questions.question:
Question 9: Given below is an electron microscopy picture of lysosomes. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Electron microscopy showing zebra bodies is suggestive of Niemann–Pick disease. Zebra bodies are engorged secondary lysosomes that contain membranous cytoplasmic bodies 
resembling concentric lamellated myelin figures. Similar zebra bodies can also be seen in 
mucopolysaccharidoses.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following statements is false regarding I-cell disease?

options.a: It is characterised by defective phosphorylating enzymes
options.b: It is a glycogen storage disorder
options.c: It is associated with gingival hyperplasia
options.d: High levels of hydrolytic enzymes in plasma are seen

questions.explanation:
Inclusion-cell (I-cell) disease, also referred to as mucolipidosis II, is a part of the lysosomal 
storage disease family. It is characterized by the deficiency of phosphorylating enzymes essential for the formation of 
the mannose-6-phosphate recognition marker. Acid hydrolases lacking the recognition marker cannot be targeted to the lysosomes but are 
secreted extracellularly. It is characterized by: 173 
Sold by @itachibot • Coarse facial features • Gingival hyperplasia • Clouded corneas • Restricted joint movements • Claw hand deformities • Kyphoscoliosis • High plasma levels of lysosomal enzymes

questions.question:
Question 11: 167 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is false about mucopolysaccharidosis?

options.a: Hunter syndrome is due to a deficiency of iduronate 2-sulphatase
options.b: Hurler syndrome is due to a deficiency of -L-iduronidase
options.c: They are inherited as autosomal recessive traits, except Hunter syndrome
options.d: Hunter syndrome is inherited as an autosomal dominant disease

questions.explanation:
All the mucopolysaccharidoses are inherited as autosomal-recessive traits except Hunter 
syndrome. It is inherited as an X-linked recessive disease. The mucopolysaccharidoses (MPSs) are a group of closely related syndromes that result from 
genetically determined deficiencies of enzymes involved in the degradation of 
mucopolysaccharides (glycosaminoglycans). Mucopolysaccharides are abundant in the ground substance of connective tissues. In the absence 
of enzymes involved in their degradation, they accumulate within lysosomes in various tissues and 
organs of the body. Two among these are: • Hurler syndrome - deficiency of -L-iduronidase • Hunter syndrome - deficiency of iduronate 2-sulphatase

questions.question: Question 12: Which glycogen storage disorder is a lysosomal storage disease?
questions.explanation:
174 
Sold by @itachibot Glycogen storage disorder type II, also called Pompe disease, is the only glycogen storage 
disease with a defect in lysosomal metabolism. It is an autosomal-recessive metabolic disorder. It is caused by the accumulation of glycogen in 
the lysosome due to deficiency of the lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase enzyme.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 4-year-old boy presented with severe pain in his left leg which worsened over the last few 
months. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly and developmental delays were noticed. Labs 
revealed the following findings on light and oil immersion respectively of the bone marrow 
aspiration. Which of the following is deficient in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and bone marrow aspiration images showing necrotic bone with lack of 
osteocytes in the lacunae (Image A) and Gaucher cells (Image B)are suggestive of Gaucher's 
disease. This condition has a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase. Gaucher cells are plump macrophages that characteristically have a crumpled tissue paper 
appearance (Image B) of the cytoplasm. It is due to the accumulation of glucocerebrosides. They can be seen in Virchow–Robin spaces (perivascular fluid-filled cavities that surround 
perforating arteries and veins in the brain parenchyma) in patients with cerebral involvement.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 1-year-old child presents with growth retardation and abdominal distension. On 
examination, the child has characteristic doll-like facies with thin extremities. Blood 
investigations reveal hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia. USG 
abdomen shows hepatomegaly and renomegaly. What deficiency causes the given clinical 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of von Gierke disease. It is due to the deficiency of glucose 
6 phosphatase enzyme. The condition usually manifests as: 175 
Sold by @itachibot • Failure to thrive • Stunted growth • Hepatomegaly • Renomegaly Hypoglycemia is due to the failure of glucose mobilization which often leads to convulsions. Lactic 
acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia result from deranged glucose metabolism. Many 
patients also develop gout, skin xanthomas, and bleeding tendency (due to platelet dysfunction). With treatment, most patients survive and develop late complications (e.g., hepatic adenomas).

questions.question: Question 16: Which enzyme is deficient in McArdle’s syndrome?
questions.explanation:
McArdle’s syndrome is caused due to the deficiency of muscle phosphorylase. In the skeletal muscles, as opposed to the liver, glycogen is used predominantly as a source of 
energy during physical activity. If enzymes hydrolyzing glucose are deficient, there will be an 
accumulation of glycogen in the muscles. This will cause muscle weakness due to impaired energy 
production. Enzyme deficiencies leading to muscle glycogen storage include: • McArdle disease/type V glycogenosis - deficiency of muscle phosphorylase • Type VII glycogen storage disease - deficiency of muscle phosphofructokinase Typically, individuals with myopathic forms present with muscle cramps after exercise. This is 
because lactate levels in the blood fail to rise after exercise due to a block in glycolysis. 176 
Sold by @itachibot Chromosomal Disorders and Other Genetic Disorders
